Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Moral and Ethical Understandings of Risk, Investment and Financial Loss Following Financial Crises

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Financial bubbles are known for the sustained socioeconomic impacts that they can have on communities. In an attempt to prevent them as well as minimize the damage that the bursting of such bubbles cause, social scientists have attempted to understand the moral and ethical factors that motivate the assumption of unusual risks, as well as propensities for the repayment of debt. This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous, empirically-grounded scientific fieldwork, asks how those impacted by financial crises make moral and ethical sense of risk, investment, and financial loss in their economic recovery efforts. The research will produce data important in the evaluation and resolution of financial crises.

Andrew Haxby, under the supervision of Dr. Thomas Fricke of the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, will explore how the collapse of financial bubbles influence understandings of morality, honor and kinship within their homes and communities. The research seeks to understand this relationship by exploring a housing bubble collapse in Kathmandu, Nepal from 2007 to 2011, when numerous families in the city assumed large debts in order to participate in the booming real estate market. The research takes place in Kathmandu, which is an appropriate social laboratory because it has undergone rapid urban development in the last decade, prompting various credit options for households. Families are commonly held responsible for the debts of all their members, yet creditors do not always agree on who they consider to be part of a given family, or even what constitutes responsible behavior for households facing default. Consequently, families in default must navigate between contradictory understandings of households and perceptions of responsible behavior. Yet these differences can be a boon as well as a burden. By moving their debt between creditors, and their assets between kin, families make it possible to improve their financial position, even if only temporarily. Thus, the project examines how these families are able to maneuver their way towards financial stability, hypothesizing that a family's ability to do this successfully hinges on whether or not they are able to present themselves as honorable to their creditors. The research will rely on ethnographic methods (participant observation of carefully selected informants, semi-structured interviews, and financial diaries) and socio-spatial mappings of local credit markets and household financial decision-making structures. In this way, not only does this project explore debt and families in Kathmandu, it also explores how a housing bubble changes culturally specific values. The research findings will further discussions on the anthropology of debt and ethics as well as understanding the rationales informing household financial decision-making.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explores how the virtues, responsibilities, and obligations of kinship are informing the tumultuous urbanization of Kathmandu. In particular, it focuses on the relationship between Kathmandu households, debt, and land, exploring the emerging financial, bureaucratic and social relations within this quickly modernizing economy. Despite its extraordinarily high price, land remains valued as primarily as the moral and material center of the family, and as such, its transformation into a commodity is a difficult process, and one often carried out within the obscure dealings of informal brokers. Yet Kathmandu land is simultaneously the lifeblood of Nepal’s financial sector, both its main form of collateral and source of investment. This has created a morally complex situation, in which land is circulated among families, banks, and microfinance, and through a variety of middlemen, all the while landowning families adjusting to the newfound financial value of their land. My project investigates both this economic system and the strategies through which families engage it, focusing particularly on two crises: a housing bubble collapse in 2010, and the major earthquake of 2015. Both these crises brought the moral complexities of this system to the fore, highlighting the ways by which the values of land, and the virtues of kinship, are changing in Kathmandu.

 

In specific, my research has uncovered the following:

1) The process of buying land in Nepal is made deeply obscure by the work of informal brokers or "dalaals" who capitalize on its obscurity in order to profit. This is slightly ironic since through the process of making a sale, through which land becomes legible to the state, is also mediated by these same brokers. 

2) While the work of brokers obscures the land market, commercial banks work to make it more 'transparent" through the requirements of collateralization and their use of third-party evaluators who create documentary artifacts that frame and actualize the market values of land. In this way, banks help to make the financial/market value of land paramount and long-lasting.

3) Land in a family retains a deep moral value, the corner stone of a kin groups honor. This land is then bought and sold within a market that is mostly accessible to informal brokers, who form their own community, and whose honor rests in their ability to close deals. Land in turn is financed by banks that work between the ethical poles of trust and transparency, translating uncertainty into calculable risk, and back into uncertainty as bankers bypass requirements for "trusted" clients. 

4) Bank requirements for income, and for cosigning among kin members, further work to codify kinship obligations for the purpose of making risk calculable. In doing so, they create a new space for strategic performance for families, where family members must portray their interior workings as transparent so that they can receive loans. Such performances in turn intersect, and often times contradict, traditional financial roles among kin. 

5) Complications like these both strengthen and strain the relationships between family members, while also creating the contexts within which kinship is enacted. Indeed, kinship exists as a kind of future plan of cyclical reproduction that must be brought into sync with numerous schedules and requirements: loan payments, income payments, marriages, deaths, education fees, fees for sending family members to work abroad, etc. All these considerations are both temporal and ethical, as well as rational. Thus kinship can be seen as the strategic enactment and maintenance of virtue over time. 

6) Such complications are particularly noticeable during periods of crisis. After the housing bubble collapsed, families who had invested heavily in land  struggled with how to repay loans, not only to banks but also to kin, which in turn meant their relatives struggled with their own obligations to these relatives. Likewise, after the earthquake, when families were struggling to rebuild their homes, the financial strain manifested itself in the division of numerous households as family members realized they no longer were able to work together as a single unit.
